review:
It’s OGRE. The UI is OK. I only have a couple of quibbles with it.

It’s also GEV. You get advanced terrain and overrun rules, if you want them. Ogres are murder machines with ram rules; they’re still murder machines with overrun rules. You never, ever want to overrun infantry entrenched in town hexes (double INF firepower and defense) unless it’s an Ogre doing the overrunning (double Ogre attack strength). GEVs in swamps are a Bad Idea.

Only the good parts of SHOCKWAVE, which means no friggin’ laser towers or cruise missiles. Which is is good. You get strongpoints.

You get all of the rest of the units you'd expect and none of the stupid ones; e.g. Vulcan.

Presentation is barebones as hell; functional enough, but I’m looking forward to being able to mod in painted units.
You get to make your own scenarios and maps. The official scenarios are included.

Not too sure about defender AI; I played through a MkIII scenario yesterday and just facerolled the defense.  Then again, the poor defenders did get some crap tread attack rolls. (Note: tread attack rolls WILL take years off your life as the defender).  I haven't played against an Ogre (which actually had a decent AI back in the Origin Ogre days) or a non-Ogre mixed unit fight.  Multiplayer is, of course, available.  Which means you don't get to throw dice at your opponent when your sixteenth tread attack a row misses.

So, if you want OGRE/GEV on the PC, well, you’ve got it!  Every old Pocket Box grognard needs to pick this up now.  You millennial social media kids: well, honestly, I don't know.  There's grogs in every generation, though, so you kids might want to pick it up anyway to learn the ancient street knowledge of CRTs (Combat Result Tables) and IGO-UGO.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995252962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 546, 'last_played': 1635448557}
review:
Ogre is a fine implementation of the board game, including some content from the GEV standalone expansion.  There are no GEV scenarios included (update 12/04 - there are some now) but there is an editor and there will probably be some popping up on Steam Workshop soon.  All of the scenarios from the original OGRE game are in.  There is also a campaign mode "Nightfall" which I haven't yet tried.  There is a tutorial, it seemed solid but as I am not new to the game I can't say for sure.  It did teach the interface well enough!

Ogre needs some UI polish and AI improvements (especially when playing the defense).  For example, it shouldn't set up in a way that lets me launch 6 missiles at its GEVs on turn 1.  The AI did play its endgame perfectly (1 missile tank vs my 2 move weaponless OGRE, stayed out of ramming range while shooting every turn, I even tried pinning it against the map edge but it avoided that).  The interface is a bit click-heavy, if more keyboard shortcuts are added that would be fine.  Additionally, popups can obscure other information.

So far the dev seems responsive so I expect the interface and bugs to improve, but it's only been a day.  I would recommend the game to OGRE fans but not necessarily everybody at this point.

Update: Some GEV scenarios are added, the AI remains pretty laughable particularly when it comes to moving GEVs or being aggressive under a timer such as Breakthrough (and I am not an expert! - I am playing these scenarios for the first time here).  Still hopeful - adding stack movement was a great addition so I'm still on the devs' side :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970500236', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 4830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 713, 'last_played': 1712207707}
review:
Truly a faithful adaptation of a classic science fiction warsim from way back in the late 70s and early 80s, this game doesn't play fast and loose like other computer adaptations, but just keeps the basic simple mechanic and setting that made Ogre fun and playable.

If you're looking for some flashy RTS with eye-popping effects and loud soundtrack, then this is not the game for you.  This is a turn based tactical tank sim, not a resource managing click fest.  The graphics, the map and models, are true to the classic game, and the added music and sound effects are just right and appropriate without being overstated.

Ogre is a basic wargame about futuristic cyber tanks that dominate the battlefield.  "Back in the day" it was fun to play, and if you've been waiting for a digital port, then look no further, because here it is.

Good fun, reasonably priced.  

Check it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040233068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1644771109}
review:
Love this game. I played this as a kid and this is very faithful to the original game. It basically is the game, just on the computer and with more scenarios and the option to play against AI's.

It's even more fun than the board game because the computer keeps track of everything for you. A game that would take two hours played by hand (75% of that time being keeping track of what moved, what was damaged how much, rolling dice, and figuring out attack ratios) takes only 30 minutes in this. And all of that time is action. The computer does all the tedious stuff for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055885447', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1534294231}
review:
A perfect recreation of the classic tabletop board game. If you have fond memories of playing Ogre like I do, this is the game you are looking for. 

If you are new to the Ogre franchise, this game plays exactly like a boardgame, down to the dice rolling mechanics. The main focus of the game is combat between Ogres, massive tanks that have the firepower of a small army. One team plays the Ogre, and the other team plays a small force trying to defend a command post. Both players need to be strategic with their attacks and movement.

If you enjoy strategy based war games, Ogre is perfect for you. The only drawback so far is the lack of players online, but that will hopefully change soon enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975732248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1507810384}
review:
Abysmal interface. Sucks a lot of the pleasure from the game. Movement is a real chore. There is very little feedback from the UI as to what you are doing, which leads to mistakes in movement in particular.

They appear to have fixed some of the more glaring bugs, like being unable to attack roads, which is a type of bug that frankly should not have passed QA in a title in this price range.

Considering the price tag I would have expected a much higher level of polish to be honest, there are games that cost a fraction of this that manage to do a better job of presentation and design.

Overall, this is a dogmatic port of a tabletop game, that makes no concessions to the fact it is now digital. While this will invariably please the most hardcore fans of the original tabletop version, it does nothing to endear it to anyone who values playability.

developer_response:
Hi there Badajoz - really sorry to hear about your initial issues with the game! I'd just like to address a couple of your concerns and how we've approached them.

There is now a combat log which lists every attack, successful or unsuccessful, including the dice roll result and which unit attacked what - this should help make combat sequences clearer and less confusing. We've also created [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/517780/discussions/0/1489987634020854823/]a few videos[/url] which explain some the intricacies of the UI which might be useful to you and anyone else reading this :)

We've also added a speed toggle in the game so that you can speed up animations and movement without having to turn all the animations off completely.

We'll be adding a 'Confirm' to the End Phase button when you have units which haven't attacked yet, but can. There was a smaller fix for this issue added where the End Phase button would only become highlighted when you'd finished attacking, but this wasn't perfect so we want to make doubly sure. In addition to this, we're adding a 'stack movement' option in this week's planned update.

For a complete list of fixes and new features, check out this thread [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/517780/discussions/1/2765630416826204812/]here[/url].

We hope to see you back on the battlefield soon, and that your experience is a more enjoyable one this time!

review:
I should be writing a lengthy, eloquent review. Instead I'm spending hours playing through the Nightfall campaign. The first few missions are deceptively easy, but the difficulty level ramps up nicely in subsequent battles. The Nightfall Ogres are a great use of computer AI for a single-player campaign.

Definitely recommended for anyone who's played the Ogre tabletop game over the years!

UPDATE (17-11-22): Now that the GEV scenarios have started to appear, I can try out some of the games that were a little too fiddly for easy tabletop sessions. The AI can be a bit simple-minded, but that's what the multiplayer scenarios are for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017846115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1507700745}
review:
I initially gave this a thumbs down due to the tutorial repeatedly getting stuck, but since then, the issue has been fixed -- kudos to the dev for the quick response.

The game is a great recreation of the tabletop game, and having the computer track attack:defense ratios and which units have moved is a welcome addition for anyone who has played the analog version.

The single-player campaign is quite fun so far, and offers some interesting win/fail conditions in some scenarios that force you to adapt your strategy.

Even having only played part of the campaign, I'm now happy to recommend this.
